article.title: UCSB, Isla Vista Locations Close in Response to Poor Air Quality
article.description: The map shows locations in I.V. and on campus that are closed Friday or providing limited services.
article.content:
Several locations on the UC Santa Barbara campus and in Isla Vista have closed due to poor air quality as a result of the Thomas Fire burning in Ventura County, while others are operating with limited services.

The map below shows locations in I.V. and on campus that are closed Friday or providing limited services.

The following departments will be closed Friday:

  • Academic Initiatives
  • Visitors Center
  • A.S. Bike Shop
  • A.S. Food Bank
  • A.S. Program Board
  • Campus Learning Assistance Services (CLAS)
  • Career Services
  • Children’s Centers
  • College of Engineering – Undergraduate Office
  • Disabled Students Program (DSP)
  • Early Academic Outreach Program (EAOP)
  • Educational Opportunity Program (EOP)
  • First-Year and Graduate Student Initiatives
  • Office of Financial Aid and Scholarships
  • Gevirtz Graduate School of Education (GGSE)
  • Health and Wellness
  • Office of Judicial Affairs (OJA)
  • MultiCultural Center (MCC)
  • Pardall Center
  • Resource Center for Sexual and Gender Diversity (RCSGD)
  • Student Affairs Grants and Development
  • Student Information Systems and Technology (SIS&T)
  • Office of Student Life (OSL)
  • ONDAS Student Center
  • Orientation Programs and Parent Services
  • Storke Student Publications
  • Undocumented Student Services
  • Veterans and Military Services
  • Women, Gender and Sexual Equity (WGSE)
  • Non-Traditional Student Resource Center

Updated 10:35 a.m. 12/8/17

Updated 12:17 p.m. 12/8/17

Updated 12:12 p.m. 

Print
Evelyn Spence

related.title: Bike Sharing Program Soon To Reach Isla Vista, UCSB
related.description: UC Santa Barbara and the Santa Barbara Public Works department will be implementing a bike sharing program that will span across both Isla Vista and the UCSB campus.
related.content:
UC Santa Barbara and the Santa Barbara Public Works department will be implementing a bike sharing program that will span across both Isla Vista and the UCSB campus.

Every CSD board member supported the program, but a few members expressed skepticism about the program not having a permanent bike rack for students to park in. Nexus File Photo

The program, co-sponsored by the Isla Vista Community Services District (I.V. CSD), will allow individuals to borrow one of the 1,200 bicycles that will be available.

Currently, there are approximately 20,000 registered bicycles within UCSB and I.V.’s two square miles, according to the Associated Students Bicycle Committee.

Matt Dobberteen, alternative transport manager from the Santa Barbara Public Works department, presented the program to the I.V. CSD alongside Mo Lovegreen, UCSB director of campus sustainability, on Tuesday night.

“We’re looking at a potential launch date of June 25, 2018, for the first allocation of 600 bikes in the area,” Dobberteen said.

Following the first launch date, an additional 600 bikes will arrive in August, he explained.

Each bike has an individual GPS tracking unit and bike lock attached, according to Dobberteen. This eliminates the need for a bike rack and lowers the chances of theft.

Currently, the I.V. CSD is trying to find parking spaces for the bicycles.

Every CSD board member supported the program, but a few members expressed skepticism about the program not having a permanent bike rack for students to park in.

CSD Director Jay Freeman questioned how students would be prevented from leaving the bikes piled up on the side of the street.

Dobberteen said watching the flow of bikes and where they end up will be an important learning tool.

“If there are heaps of bikes all over, we have failed,” he said.

Dobberteen said potential solutions include giving students incentives to return bikes to a designated location in the evening or hiring a company that would park the bicycles in a designated location during the night.

Lovegreen added that UCSB’s Department of Campus Sustainability also has plans to start a new outreach program for the bike sharing service starting next week. The program is directed at incoming freshmen in an attempt to persuade them to not bring their own bikes.

The board of directors said the central problem with the program is finding the space for the bikes and persuading students to use the bikes in a respectful manner.

“This is about us bringing high quality transportation to the community, and if we are respectful, it benefits everyone,” Dobberteen added.

A version of this article appeared on p.1 of the April 26 print edition of the Daily Nexus.

Print

related.title: Associated Students Elections 2018
related.description: The official ballot will be available on G.O.L.D.  from April 23 to April 26. Election results will be announced on Thursday, April 26 at 7 p.m.
related.content:
Jose Ochoa/Daily Nexus

Associated Students Elections Board released in March its official list of candidates seeking elected office this Spring 2018.

There are a total of 52 candidates running for A.S. positions, most of whom fall under one of two parties: Campus United and the Isla Vista Party. Ten of those candidates are running for executive positions.

The site below is intended to educate voters on each candidate’s platform and intentions if elected to office. Stay connected with the Nexus for live election results announced in the Hub of the University Center on Thursday evening.

http://dailynexus.com/interactives/aselections2018/

The Nexus interviewed the ten A.S. executive candidates last week and endorsed the candidates we believe will best fill the position for the 2018-2019 academic year. Our endorsements can be accessed below.

A.S. President

Internal Vice President

External Vice President for Statewide Affairs

External Vice President for Local Affairs

Student Advocate General

Students can vote on G.O.L.D. from April 23 to April 26. Election results will be announced on Thursday, April 26 at 7 p.m.

related.title: Eight A.S. Exec. Candidates Do Not Support UCen Renovation, Which Would Raise Student Fees
related.description: Eight candidates running for an A.S. executive position denounced the proposed “NewCen” ballot measure, which would raise student fees to fund the University Center renovation.
related.content:
Eight candidates running for an Associated Students executive position denounced the proposed “NewCen” ballot measure, which would raise student fees to fund the University Center renovation.

Eight Associated Students executive candidates have publicly opposed the University Center renovation. From top left to right, Sophia Dycaico, Anthony Pimentel, Brooke Kopel and Mayela Morales. From bottom left to right, Jeike Meijer, Steven Ho, Justice Dumlao and Madeline Loudon. Jose Ochoa, Tamari Dzotsenidze / Daily Nexus

On Sunday night, Brooke Kopel, the candidate for A.S. president running with Campus United (CU), released a statement on Facebook denouncing the ballot measure.

“I want to be very clear: students should not have to pay a penny more in student fees for a new UCen,” the statement said. “The UCen as it exists has so many problem [sic]: it’s old, crowded, and it needs renovation- just like tons of other buildings on our campus. This isn’t because student fees are too low, it’s because California refuses to invest in public education.”

The statement was released a couple of hours before voting officially opened on G.O.L.D.

In an interview with the Nexus, Kopel said she wanted to be as transparent as possible with students and she believes that students pay the most attention right before voting starts.

“That’s why I wanted to release it at that point, not to get any last minute votes or as a way to put myself up in the elections, but rather to reach as many students as possible when they’re paying attention,” Kopel said.

CU executive candidates Sophia Dycaico, the candidate for Executive Vice President for Local Affairs (EVPLA), Madeline Loudon, the candidate for Executive Vice President for Statewide Affairs (EVPSA) and Anthony Pimentel, the candidate for Internal Vice President (IVP), all confirmed they agree with Kopel’s statement.

Dycaico said she had always denounced the raising of student fees to renovate the UCen. Both Dycaico and Kopel told the Nexus on Monday they believed an official statement was necessary to dispel rumours that Campus United supported the “NewCen” measure as a party.

Many candidates support the renovation of the UCen; however, they disagree with raising student fees to complete the renovation.

“I think that funding should be coming from the state and the UC system and should definitely not be placed as a burden on students,” Loudon said.  

Jeike Meijer, the candidate for EVPLA with the Isla Vista Party, said that making students pay for the UCen sets a precedent for students paying for all on-campus renovations.  

All four candidates running for executive positions with the Isla Vista Party also confirmed they do not support the raising of student fees to renovate the UCen.

Many of them denounced the project before election season began, including Justice Dumlao, the IVP candidate for A.S. president.

“While I’m very glad that she finally is coming out in being against the NewCen project, I think it was just a little late,” Dumlao said. “I’m a little sad that it was late, but better late than never.”

Dumlao said he thought Kopel could have been more open about the fact that she was questioning her position on the NewCen project.

Dumlao added that he believes Kopel might have felt she could not express her opinions on the ballot measure, as Hieu Le, the current A.S. President and main proponent of the “NewCen” project, ran with Campus United and is affiliated with the same party as Kopel.

“I don’t want to pin it all on Brooke… I imagine it’s very difficult to denounce something that your current elected president is doing,” Dumlao said. “‘Better late than never’ is how I feel. There’s so many other circumstances that Brooke could have been under or pressured under.”

When asked why she took a stance on the ballot so late in the election season, Kopel said she wanted to gather as much information as possible before making a decision and said she felt as though new facts were coming out about the UCen proposal everyday.

“I actually wanted to wait as long as I could to hear the most opinions I could,” Kopel added. “That is my job, to understand everybody’s ultimate sentiments toward this project.”

Mayela Morales, the candidate for External Vice President for Statewide Affairs with the Isla Vista Party, also commented on the timing of Kopel’s statement.

“I was a little disheartened to see Brooke coming out with the statement not because I don’t believe that she’s against it, but because students have been so vocal about it for a really long time,” Morales said. “I thought it was very strategic to post that right before voting started.”

“It is always ‘better late than never,’ but I honestly think it was a little too late for her to say that,” Morales added. “I think it was a little too strategic; she could have said that a long time ago.”

Print
Simren Verma

Simren Verma currently serves as the University News Editor. She also enjoys school and the presence of her news team.
